contentSections.title: Tree Shaking for Web
contentSections.content:
**Tree Shaking** removes unused code from your final bundle:

**How it works:**
1. Compiler analyzes your code
2. Identifies unused classes, methods, functions
3. Removes them from the final build

**Best practices:**
- Avoid dynamic imports when possible
- Use `const` constructors
- Don't import entire packages if you only need one class
- Use conditional imports for platform-specific code

```dart
// Bad: Imports everything
import 'package:huge_library/huge_library.dart';

// Good: Import only what you need
import 'package:huge_library/specific_widget.dart';
```

contentSections.title: Lazy Loading and Deferred Components
Image Optimization
Font Optimization
contentSections.content:
**Font Loading Strategies:**

1. **Use System Fonts When Possible:**
```dart
ThemeData(
  fontFamily: 'system-ui', // Uses native system font
)
```

2. **Subset Custom Fonts:**
Only include characters you need:
```yaml
flutter:
  fonts:
    - family: CustomFont
      fonts:
        - asset: fonts/CustomFont.ttf
```

3. **Preload Critical Fonts:**
```html
<link rel="preload" href="assets/fonts/main.ttf" as="font" crossorigin>
```

4. **Use font-display: swap:**
Shows system font while custom font loads.

contentSections.content:
**Vercel** offers excellent performance and simple deployment:

**Setup:**
```bash
# Install Vercel CLI
npm install -g vercel

# Login

```

**Create vercel.json in project root:**
```json
{
  "buildCommand": "flutter build web --wasm",
  "outputDirectory": "build/web",
  "framework": null,
  "rewrites": [
    { "source": "/(.*)", "destination": "/index.html" }

```


contentSections.title: Netlify Deployment
contentSections.content: Netlify provides a simple deployment workflow for Flutter web apps. Configure your build settings in netlify.toml and connect your GitHub repository for automatic deployments.

# netlify.toml in project root
[build]
  command = "flutter build web --wasm"
  publish = "build/web"

[[redirects]]
  from = "/*"
  to = "/index.html"
  status = 200

# Deploy via CLI:
# npm install -g netlify-cli
# netlify login
# netlify deploy --prod

# Or connect GitHub repo for automatic deploys

contentSections.title: GitHub Pages Deployment
contentSections.content:
**GitHub Pages** is free and integrates with your repository:

**Method 1: Manual**
```bash
flutter build web --wasm --base-href "/your-repo-name/"

# Copy build/web contents to gh-pages branch
```

**Method 2: GitHub Actions**
```yaml
# .github/workflows/deploy.yml
name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: subosito/flutter-action@v2
        with:
          flutter-version: '3.22.0'
      - run: flutter build web --wasm --base-href "/${{ github.event.repository.name }}/"
      - uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./build/web
```

**Important:** Set `--base-href` for GitHub Pages!

modules.title: Module 15: Offline-First Architecture with Drift & Isar
modules.description: Build resilient mobile apps with type-safe local databases, offline sync strategies, and local-first architecture patterns.

contentSections.title: Why Offline-First?
contentSections.content:
**Users Expect Apps to Work Without Internet**

Think about how you use your phone. You're on a subway with spotty signal, in an airplane with no WiFi, or in a building with poor reception. What happens when you open an app?

With **online-first** apps, you see spinning loaders, error messages, or blank screens. Frustrating.

With **offline-first** apps, everything loads instantly. You can read, write, and interact. When connection returns, changes sync automatically.

**Real-world examples:**
- Notes apps (you expect to read your notes anywhere)
- Todo lists (you want to check items off offline)
- Email (you can read and compose offline)
- Maps (downloaded areas work without signal)

contentSections.title: The Problem with Online-First
contentSections.content:
**Online-First Architecture:**
```
User Action -> API Request -> Wait for Response -> Update UI
```

**Problems:**
1. **Slow perceived performance** - Users wait for every action
2. **Network dependency** - App is useless without internet
3. **Poor UX on slow connections** - 3G users have terrible experience
4. **Data loss risk** - If request fails mid-submission, data is lost
5. **Battery drain** - Constant network activity

**Statistics:**
- 53% of users abandon sites that take >3 seconds to load
- Mobile connections average 50-200ms latency per request
- Users check phones 150+ times/day, often briefly

contentSections.title: Local is Truth, Remote is Backup
contentSections.content:
**The Offline-First Mindset:**

Instead of treating the server as the source of truth and local storage as a cache, flip it:

- **Local database is the primary source** - App reads/writes here first
- **Remote server is backup** - Syncs when connection is available
- **Changes sync bidirectionally** - Local to remote, remote to local

**Benefits:**
- **Instant response** - No network wait for any action
- **Works everywhere** - Online, offline, or poor connection
- **Resilient** - Network failures don't lose data
- **Better UX** - App feels native and fast

**The key principle:** Your app should work perfectly with airplane mode on. Network is an enhancement, not a requirement.

contentSections.title: When to Use Isar vs Drift
contentSections.content:
**Choose Drift (SQL) when:**
- Complex relational data with joins
- Need SQL query flexibility
- Coming from SQL background
- Strict schema requirements
- Complex reporting queries

**Choose Isar (NoSQL) when:**
- Simple data structures
- Maximum performance is critical
- Flexible/evolving schema
- Document-style data
- Need full-text search built-in
- Want simplest possible API

**Isar Advantages:**
- **Blazing fast** - Written in Rust, optimized for mobile
- **No code generation wait** - Fast builds
- **Full-text search** - Built-in, no extra setup
- **Synchronous API** - Optional sync operations
- **Encryption** - Built-in database encryption

lessons.title: Module 15, Lesson 6: Isar Indexes & Query Optimization

contentSections.title: Index Types
contentSections.content:
**Indexes make queries fast.** Without indexes, Isar scans every record.

**Value Index (default):**
- Best for equality checks and range queries
- Stores actual values in sorted order
- Good for: `equalTo`, `greaterThan`, `between`

```dart
@Index(type: IndexType.value)
String? title; // Indexed by value
```

**Hash Index:**
- Fast equality checks only
- Smaller storage than value index
- Cannot do range queries

```dart
@Index(type: IndexType.hash)
String? email; // Only for exact matching
```

**HashElements Index (for lists):**
- Index each element in a list
- Find records containing specific values

```dart
@Index(type: IndexType.hashElements)
List<String> tags = []; // Search by tag
```

contentSections.title: Composite Indexes
contentSections.content: Index multiple fields together for compound queries:

contentSections.title: Query Performance
Filtering and Sorting
Query Optimization Tips
contentSections.content:
**Index Strategy:**
1. Index fields you filter by frequently
2. Use composite indexes for multi-field queries
3. Put most selective field first in composite index
4. Hash indexes for exact-match only fields
5. Don't over-index - each index costs write performance

**Query Tips:**
1. Use `.where()` for indexed queries (fast)
2. Use `.filter()` only for complex conditions
3. Avoid `.filter().contains()` on unindexed fields
4. Use `.count()` instead of `.findAll().length`
5. Use `.limit()` for pagination

**Debugging:**
```dart
// Enable Isar Inspector in development
final isar = await Isar.open(
  schemas,
  inspector: true, // Opens inspector on localhost:8080
);
```

contentSections.title: Sync Architecture Patterns
contentSections.content:
**The Sync Challenge:**
User edits data offline. Server has updates. How do you merge?

**Three Approaches:**

1. **Pull-Only Sync**
   - Fetch from server, overwrite local
   - Simple but loses offline changes
   - Good for: Read-only data, reference data

2. **Push-Pull Sync**
   - Push local changes, then pull remote changes
   - Requires conflict handling
   - Good for: User-generated content

3. **Real-time Sync**
   - WebSockets for instant sync
   - Complex but seamless
   - Good for: Collaboration apps

We'll build a **Push-Pull** sync with queue-based changes.

contentSections.title: Project Overview
contentSections.content:
**Build a Notes App with Offline-First Architecture**

In this project, you'll combine everything learned in this module:

**Features:**
- Create, edit, delete notes (works offline)
- Notes persist in local database
- Sync indicator shows online/offline status
- Changes queue while offline
- Auto-sync when connection restored
- Pull-to-refresh for manual sync

**Architecture:**
```
UI Layer
    |
    v
Repository (abstraction)
    |
    v
Local Database (Isar) <---> Sync Service <---> Remote API
```

**Key Principle:** UI always talks to local database. Never waits for network.

**Testing Offline Mode:**
1. Add some notes
2. Turn on airplane mode
3. Edit notes (should work instantly)
4. Turn off airplane mode
5. Watch sync indicator go green
6. Changes sync automatically
